I herewith •t fully submit my official report as state librarian, for tin nial period aiding November 80, 10 The number of volumes in the library November 30, imn, ■During the next two years from 4,000 to r>.iMx> volumes be added. No more space for shelving is available in the teis and rooms assigned to the library, and the manner of ■*ing of such additions i* 'I be much more pleasant most excellent features of •putation it has and enjoy: use of duty force* no small problem. While it und agreeable to speak of the the state's great library and of among book lovers and stu me to direct your Excellei ion to its glaring defects and immediate needs An examination of the library quarters* on the second and third floors reveals a shocking, and. may I add. shameful con dition of affairs. The rooms are illy lighted with no means of thorough ventilation or heating and a read holly in quate to the needs of the public. ! .John 11. Mkkkv. Tlit ion of the legislature was directed to this crowded con- dition, and temporary relief was provided by an appropriation ■»u for additional shelving. Should a private citizen care uo tre tor his library it would be folly: should a city so neglect public library it would be the laughing stock of (he country ound. What then, shall we say when Nebraska neglects hei irge library? Is it that the people do not care for Ixxiks? ■ ly not. Is it from indifference as to its value as an educa - tional means? A state that bens the proud distinction of hav in^r the smallest pel' cent, of illiteracy of any state in the Union is not indifferent to the value and influence of such an excellent iry.
